1126257410258030592.text:
Thanks everyone for your responses and questions— we’ve hit the 30 minute mark, I have eleventy unread Slack notifications, and that’s a wrap! 

See you at #AusCERT2019 with @Scott_Helme and @mikko and many others in just a few weeks!

1126256022450868224.text: Finally, start with a bit of a different approach than usual, i.e. “I want to teach my colleagues things that will make their lives better if they start doing this at home.” Wrangle budget for password managers, webcam covers, etc. you will get solid returns #AusCERT2019

1126255493372989441.text: If you’re doing in-person training, I highly highly highly recommend the EFF’s Security Education Companion— it’s not designed for the corp environment, but it has impactful messaging and will improve outcomes. Also, never shame people for mistakes  #AusCERT2019 (cc@mazodude)

1126254667229360128.text: If you know your audience well, in-person training tends to be most successful. There are tons of guides out there that will give you a good start, but personalizing it to what your audience cares about will make it stick best. (Will follow up with links, @mazodude) #AusCERT2019

1126254032069115904.text: This is a great question. Before you start, get to know your audience well: what methods of communication work for them? What might be fun/funny/humorous and stick in their brains? I base most of my initial policy + edu around a doc from a few years ago by 37Signals. #AusCERT2019https://twitter.com/mazodude/status/1126252176391557122 …

1126253446720397312.text: Cross-functional security teams for the win. In the absence of an entire team, look for someone who is interdisciplinary and skilled in the art of conversation and solving problems constructively. #AusCERT2019https://twitter.com/cybersecurerobi/status/1126252920503095297 …

1126253144168472577.text: If it’s just you, the top-down approach won’t work. Look for opportunities when teams request security support/help/input and build from there. If you tell devs or IT to do something, they likely won’t be enthused. If they come to you for help, success follows  #AusCERT2019

1126252272046882817.text: If you’re a first-hire or part of a very small security team, part of success is figuring out how to align incentives with other teams to get work done. This requires understanding the goals/priorities and then getting very good at marketing your wares to others. #AusCERT2019

1126251662702567424.text:
Another #AusCERT2019 question from the DMs— yes, this is a totally appropriate way to have good opsec if your boss is on Twitter. 

“I am the only person in my organization working on security. What can I do now to build or improve relationships with other teams?"

1126250529619828737.text: Completely agree. Inventory is one of the biggest overlooked problems in the entire security industry, and not being able to explain how/why things work is a very clear indicator of risk. #AusCERT2019 https://twitter.com/rmd1023/status/1126247466221953026 …

1126250049355128833.text: Installing the latest state-of-the-art security tooling might seem like a good way to rack up an early win, but buyer beware: security is a process and not a product and buying a tool doesn’t result in an instant remediation or a more mature stance in security. #AusCERT2019

1126249480901128193.text: Once you’ve exhausted your investigation skills, it’s time to get to work and prioritize. Threat modeling your org and your code is key: this is where knowing common risks/pitfalls/attacks that are successful in your industry helps define defensive action #AusCERT2019

1126248439598145536.text: If you’re the first hire, it’s likely that you’re the first person to ever ask for documentation + diagrams and the first to ask clarifying questions, too. Go on an information gathering mission, and find allies who will champion and help scale your work #AusCERT2019

1126247811408785408.text: It is vital to understand your org and its processes, and sometimes valuable to start out on a listening tour. Find out how inventory is managed (if at all), examine how accounts are provisioned and access granted/revoked. Lots of risk hides in these processes.  #AusCERT2019

1126247360248500224.text: Knowing where to get started if you’re the first security hire can feel overwhelming. It’s important to know your threat model, have an understanding of where your org is on the basics, and to have a systematic approach to identifying, prioritizing, remediating risk. #AusCERT2019

1126246743899684864.text: Pulling a question from my DMs to get started: “Where do you start if you are the first security engineer hired into an organization?” #AusCERT2019

1116832817176907776.text:
It's kind of unbelievable and amazing that a little internet connected camera empowered us and made us feel closer together during the worst of our times together.

Surveillance isn't always bad. Technology can have a positive impact. You just have to use them the right way.

1116831772015091717.text:
I am still watching, but even though I'm 3,000 miles away, my Grandfather feels safe, loved, and protected. He still says hello, and once in awhile I even whisper "BOO!" if I get an alert when he's coming home. 

I occasionally offer to tell off unwelcome visitors for him, too.

1116831062372409344.text:
My family I ever really knew is much tinier now. It's just me and my Grandfather, and we're all we've got. 

Because it's just him and the dog now, I am still on the lookout. If I don't see him take the dog out, he knows someone is coming to check and make sure he's okay

1116830015243481089.text:
As I kept an eye out for her, I saw her come and go, even noticed how weak she was the last time that she left her home.

She left us so quickly, passing away within just a few days of me flying out. But she felt safe and at peace, in part because I was watching over them.

1116828144726491138.text:
Within a day of installing the video doorbell, something happened that made my heart pretty much explode. 

My Grandfather would stop and say hello to me through it, because he knew I was watching and I'd see it. He'd even tell the dog to say hello, too.

1116827415232122880.text:
Installing video surveillance equipment for my grandparents gave them and me peace of mind, and it gave us the ability to document and act on unprecedented ugliness. 

Instead of feeling powerless in the face of familial abuse, we could do something about it. Even from a distance

1116826391989764097.text:
The last voicemail I have from my Grandma before her voice grew weak is a message thanking me for helping, and telling me that she felt better knowing that I was watching and that I was looking out for her. 

Surveillance is not always a bad thing. It can reduce harm.

1116825317627219968.text: While we were setting up our own little monitoring and detection traps, I checked in with my grandparents to ensure I had their consent to be an admin for their home. It was my job to review when people came and went from the house and save video clips if things got out of hand.

1116824872980602880.text: After finding an installer who was willing to set things up for a customer who was 3,000 miles away.... and after my husband (who is the best and has the patience of a literal saint) walked two 70+ year old folks through setting up Google Wifi, we were ready for anything.

1116824349086846977.text:
After an awful incident where a family member tried breaking. into. their. home, I insisted on installing security cameras and coached them on how to enforce boundaries and reduce the emotional toll that these attacks and behaviors had on them. 

That's where @nest came in.

1116823745677496320.text:
In the last 6 weeks of my Grandma's life, threats, abuse and harassment were at an all-time high. She deserved better.

Because I live across the country, there wasn't much I could to directly protect her... except encourage that she document this behavior and call the police.

1116822959602094080.text:
One of the worst things about my Grandma's diagnosis was that it was the signal to toxic, abusive family members that this was last opportunity for them to settle old scores and get revenge for things from decades ago.

Hard times can bring out the best or worst in people.

1098661876206948353.text: The tl;dr here is pretty simple: We have made long-term investments in applications security, and we are working diligently to make reports, timelines, and audit information public and accessible to our community. They'll be ready for prime time very soon.

1098661007218552832.text: In addition to our ongoing audits, we've also had adversarial testnets and an active bug bounty program that surfaces valuable bugs from our incredible (and smart) community. Those contributions are a key player in our overall application security, too.

1098660098027601921.text:
So what does this all mean? And when will specific information be available? 

There isn't a list of reports or auditors that can be shared publicly yet (coordination is ongoing), but I've been working on a post that includes reports we can publish, executive summaries, etc.

1098659038403821569.text: (Side note: we've got some extra audit time with our Q2 2018 auditors to use, so we intend on using that to spot-check some of the changes to #Tendermint code.)

1098658452463771648.text: The audit cycle that kicks off in March will include #CosmosSDK modules, and will also cover software that is in alpha state and not fully production-ready #CosmosVoyager, and our KMS.

1098657979132403713.text:
In the audits we've completed so far, no critical issues have been surfaced. 

At this very moment, the #CosmosSDK is still under active assessment: we are in the middle of another audit which will draw to a close in the next few weeks. And another will kick off in March.

1098657070373527552.text:
While the #Tendermint assessment lifecycle has a bit of history the #CosmosSDK lifecycle is newer, but action packed. 

To date, 2 separate firms have audited the SDK, and we currently have one audit ongoing. The first auditor looked at the SDK in Q2 2018, the second in Q1 2019.

1098656097953402880.text: In addition to the 3 audits that focused on #Tendermint, we have also lined up a series of audits to look at the #CosmosSDK.  Because the SDK interfaces with Tendermint through baseapp, each of the auditors tasked with the SDK have also spent time on important Tendermint code

1098655306706350080.text:
During Q2 + Q3 2018, two separate auditing firms kicked off assessments of Tendermint: one focused on the crypto layer, and the other on servers and the communication layer. 

Neither audit surfaced any critical severity issues in Tendermint code.

1098654115402440704.text: Starting off with #Tendermint: To date, we've engaged 3 separate firms to focus on Tendermint, and each audit has looked at different aspects of the code. In 2017, the Jepsen folks audited Tendermint and published the results here: https://jepsen.io/analyses/tendermint-0-10-2 …

1098653336801136640.text: As the @tendermint_team is moving closer towards the first phase of @cosmos mainnet launch , there have been a few excellent questions about audits. The details are being finalized, but here's everything I can share about our assessment lifecycle for #Tendermint + #CosmosSDK

1090096371263107074.text: Anyway, this is a weird and amusing bug and it’s not the end of the world by a long shot. Turn off your FaceTime until the next security update is out so that one prankster friend doesn’t try to call you when you’re on the toilet and catch you in a compromising position

1090095874699493376.text: This guy who happens to know a lot about bugs says it rather well here  https://twitter.com/osxreverser/status/1090091475906580481?s=21 …

1090095368103112704.text: It’s really hard to figure out what this does and what the impact truly is from the reporting, and the set of steps to carry out the attack are a bit unusual and hard to truly take advantage of. You would still see evidence of a missed call for a group FaceTime

1090094750781235201.text: This bug doesn’t turn your iPad, iPhone, or MacBook into a persistent hot mic that endlessly transmits audio and video back to an attacker. What it does is feed that information to them for a much more limited amount of time, roughly around 30 seconds to a minute.

1090094107802791938.text: There’s a security bug that allows for an attacker (or prankster friend, tbh) to access audio/video data before you accept a FaceTime call from them. It’s a crappy bug, but it has limited impact and is not as awful as all of the fire and brimstone articles floating around rn

1090093535318032385.text:
If you’re an iOS or MacOS user,
it’s a really great idea to turn off FaceTime (in Settings) on all of the devices where you could receive a call right now , and avoid re-enabling it until you’ve installed your next security update.

Happy 2019, y’all! 

Encrypt the hell out of everything that makes sense in your 2019, and get to working on you privacy and security threat models now.

1079130501225435136.text:
Look, it’s been a shit year for people who just want to help others manage risk and be safe online and off. All of our wildest threat models keep coming true. Keeping up is exhausting. 

If you’re gonna hoard data, give us a way to delete it or nuke it or disassociate from it.

1079129031667109889.text:

1034536579451170816.text:
So many words have been spilled about things being secure-by-default, but maybe that term should expand to include getting security advisories without an Odyssey-like journey for info. And it should work for people who build stuff outside of the US, too. 

/fin

1034535468350636032.text: "You never went to a top tier school to learn how to write secure code so you can't write code" isn't an answer here, not when so few top tier schools even appropriately teach secure development + dep/vuln management correctly to begin with.

1034535091064561664.text: So many people in this world learning to develop and learning to write code are not from the US, will never approach creating software through our policy, and may not even have a full formal education. How do we make this better to give them some hope of success?

1034533674056740864.text: It would be so cool if we could come up with a handful of clear, direct, concise ways to deliver information that doesn't require quilting a nearly-impossible set of patch info updates into a process. There are good reasons for this.

1034533047729717248.text: Fixing broken security advisories/updates isn't a silver bullet. Coding is very much creation and speech, and to move the needle in the right direction, we need to look at current obstacles +  think critically about how to foster core security values among devs across the planet

1034532280746749952.text: Yes, hello, someone is arguing at me and now I have more things to say.

1034505689320710144.text:
Every dang time I see a "NO" in the security advisories/security page/ RSS feed column, it feels like the universe is all  and honestly... how the hell do any of us have any hope in empowering developers + building safe and secure things with this as the status quo?

/rant

1034504745560432640.text: The way we distribute security advisories and patch update information is fragmented af and it seems to be setting almost any well-meaning security team/person up for total failure. How do we improve the process for everyone, and not just people with budget for vendor tools?

1034504428785557504.text:
So yes, I am all "omg how can we make patching/dep + vuln mgmt work better, this is way too much crazy to expect everyone to do?!" ... but for real:

What tiny improvements can we start with that have a big impact? How do we get software folks flying in formation in fix mode?

1034503362178211840.text: Honestly, at this rate, most of us would spend like 5 years and way too much money on vendors + resources to try and figure out how to automate security alert delivery across this crazy patchwork of information distribution. And we'd fail. Ain't nobody got time for that!

1034502434775695360.text:
It would be so cool if there were a reliable way to disseminate security updates and patch info in a timely manner to *everyone* without needing to sign up for a million groups and lists. 

We're not going to increase time-to-patch metrics without it. So maybe let's get to work?

1034501784775999488.text: This is an incredibly difficult problem to solve, and it is one that many fancy organizations spend quite a bit of money trying to solve or improve. But what about the rest of us? Shouldn't/couldn't we have more than a million mailing lists and groups to join for info?

1034500544667181056.text: Yes, services and tooling exist to backport patches to common/popular distros of software. But not every organization can afford that (security poverty lines are real) and many developers aren't interested-- they want to use the newest + coolest features, tech, and code

1034500211001815040.text: Nothing screams "dysfunctional relationship" and "awful communication" to me more than the widespread lack of /security pages across every kind of software part imaginable-- free-range, open source code and enterprise fanciness alike.

1034499510133698561.text:
Yes, security bugs won't come marching in through the front door in a perfectly orderly fashion... but we should be able to come up with a functional, timely way for security alerts to come to us.

If we can't get alerts, how the hell can any of us patch?!

1034498692823175168.text: When I scan through software parts and see that there's no security advisory page, no security page, and that instead a well-meaning security person has to bookmark changelogs, sign up for mailing lists, and learn to read smoke signals to get security updates, I am mad as hell

1034497982886948865.text: Back to my spreadsheet though, because for real, there is a big old mess going on here...

1034497837092855808.text: Vuln management and dependency management are extra super intertwined with a process that infosec folks love to argue about ad nauseam: patch management. Some of us are on the "patching is hard and not always feasible" side, others argue "what kind of idiot doesn't patch?"

1034497347349176320.text:
Every time I open one of these spreadsheets cataloging software and software parts, the Security column pair is such a freaking disappointment. For way too many things in use in technology, "None" and "None" fill the sec advisory + sec page columns. 

THIS IS NOT OKAY

1034496943433515009.text:
One of the most important columns in the vuln/dependency management spreadsheet is the one for security advisories-- it's partner in importance is the column for security pages attached to products/packages/software.

Real talk: these are the most infuriating columns ever.

1034496480621387776.text:
I've worked on many, many of these process backbone spreadsheets, but there are a few that have really gotten under my skin lately: vulnerability management, and dependency management. 

They're kind of a big deal, but a quick scan of two important columns = instant rage.

1034496058246582273.text: (Side note: I've worked in a library and a museum before. And I f*cking love these spreadsheets so much. Don't @ me)

1034495797578981376.text: The backbone of many early iterations of security process is usually some form of a spreadsheet. It's essential to take stock of what your software is made out of, and you have to take stock of what software you're using to make software + run a business.

1034495002401886208.text: Alright, so, real talk: many of us who are trying to live our best security lives run on a handful of pretty serious mantras-- that Bruce Schneider quote about security being a process and not a product is one of the big ones.

1034494538713247744.text: Incoming: tiny or possibly not-so-tiny security rant about vuln + dependency management

1026908650936258560.text:
“How are you even qualified to speak on this?!”

Hi, once upon a time I was new to all of this. I worked for companies + supported clients during Summer Camp. I wasn’t here for any of that security fanfiction. But a lot of people don’t have the tools to call BS yet. Be better.

1026906592820654080.text: Gatekeeping behavior like performative opsec designed to scare the crap out of non-technical attendees or new folks isn’t cool either. If we are gonna be successful as a discipline, we need to be welcoming to new people who want to pitch in and use their talents to help us out

1026905925305610240.text: Scaring people and telling them you could hurt/hack them but you won’t because you’re a “white hat” or “nice guy” immensely harms our ability to connect with the people who need to change their security behavior. And it sure isn’t nice! So let’s all agree to not do that, mmmkay?

1026904877748744192.text: I’ve been on the plane for less than 20 minutes and for serious... shame on all the bad security advice to the humans going to Vegas for vacay and the weak travel opsec with information leakage, y’all!!!

1025237233865900032.text: Want to change minds about security? This is how it happens. And holy shit, it's wonderful to watch it all play out.

1025235871929327616.text: Security involves many lifestyle-level choices + decisions, and seeing discussions about privacy + security emerge in popular culture does wonderful things. It reaches new audiences, and normalizes security behavior. It positively influences + reinforces behaviors we want to see.

1025234742541660161.text: Most criticism of reality TV has nothing to do with the content of the show-- it's thinly veiled criticism of the people who watch it. Who do reality TV shows target? Mostly women. What age range watches it most? Young women anywhere from 18-24.

1025234099181514752.text: I will not listen to another word again in my life about how stupid/vapid/self-indulgent reality TV is. I will hear none of this nonsense about it being a waste of time or stupid. Every lifestyle show, every season has a few privacy + security related subplots. This is amazing.

1025233604425568256.text:

Y'all know how I will not shut up in 1:1 conversations about how reality TV is doing more than almost any other form of popular media to educate people about privacy + security? Real talk, Reza from Shahs of Sunset just told everybody to lock their dang phones

1024790456998088704.text: Walking the "stop talking shit about 2FA" and "talk about the right shit that matters when you're teaching about 2FA" line is extremely serious (and tiring) business. And y'all wonder why I freaking love shoes.

1024789658289336320.text: For-freaking-real though... using 2FA as a consumer is so much different than using 2FA in a business context. It's totally fine to educate people about 2FA's benefits, but at home we don't all get a sysadmin who can and will assist in recovery. This matters. So, so much.

1024788881860771840.text: If I have sufficient time, I'll try to make a security checklist/risk analysis thing and/or a decision tree, too. No promises though, especially since all I wanna do is nap and there's not enough time to nap in my life

1024788229189292032.text: Let's just be real right now: 2FA extremely sucks in some serious ways, and we're not going to get more people to use it if we do not acknowledge its risks. flaws + obstacles to people who want to adopt it. We have to be super honest about the work it entails. It is ALOT.

1024787359064195072.text: Yup, pretty sure it is time-- time to write that blog post that acknowledges significant user obstacles and includes everything people need to know about 2FA, including all of the stuff that the person who told you to use 2FA omitted/didn't tell you about shit that goes wrong
